Award.AwardTitle: Dynamics and geometry of free-by-cyclic groups
Award.AbstractNarration:
A group is an algebraic structure capturing the abstract properties of the collection of symmetries of a geometric object or of a physical or mechanical system. The project will concentrate on the study of free-by-cyclic groups. These groups are natural counterparts of the fundamental groups of fibered 3-manifolds, which are important mathematical objects playing key roles in Topology, Differential Geometry, Ergodic Theory, Number Theory, Computational Complexity, and other branches of Mathematics. Compared with the 3-manifold groups, the free-by-cyclic groups are much less well understood, even though they exhibit a considerably wider variety of interesting features and behavior. The project aims to study the geometry and dynamics of free-by-cyclic groups, particularly through exploring new polynomial invariants of these groups. This research should help better understand both the differences and the similarities between the free-by-cyclic groups and their 3-manifold "cousins", and lead to new insights about the interactions of algebra and dynamics in group theory.

The project will build on the new work of the proposer, joint with Leininger and Dowdall, studying the properties of free-by-cyclic groups by means of a "folded mapping torus", associated to such a group. The folded mapping torus comes equipped with a natural semi-flow of continuous transformations, and it encodes in a particularly useful and accessible form key algebraic, geometric and dynamical information about the group. Another key object, associated to the folded mapping torus, is the "McMullen polynomial", which is a free-by-cyclic analog of the Teichmuller polynomial for fibered 3-manifolds. The main overall research goal of the project is to understand algebraic, geometric and dynamical features related to the many possible ways in which a free-by-cyclic group G can split as a free-by-cyclic group and as an ascending HNN-extension of a free group, and to gain new knowledge about free group automorphisms. Specific problems to be studied include: understanding the relationship between the "cone of sections" of folded mapping torus with the BNS-invariant of the group, uniformizing the stable trees and the Cannon-Thurston maps associated with different splittings of G, studying irreducibility properties of monodromy automorphisms associated to different free-by-cyclic splittings of G, developing an analog of the homological zeta-function for G, and others.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project resulted in significant progress in the understanding of dynamics and geometry of free-by-cyclic groups. During the period of the grant the PI published over 15 research papers related to the project, including a landmark 100 page paper with Dowdall and Leininger in the prestigious Journal of the European Mathematical Society. The PI's work introduced and developed important new tools and ideas in the subject, including the folded mapping torus for free-by-cyclic groups, the McMullen polynomial, Lipschitz metrics and  Lipschitz foliations, etc. The work resulted in much deeper understanding of the BNS invariant of free-by-cyclic groups and of the connections between algebraic and dynamical properties of free group automorphisms. Other work of the PI during the grant period produced significant new results regarding the Cannon-Thurston map, regarding the index properties of ``random" free group automorphisms, and regarding non-commutative generalizations of geodesic currents. 


During the grant period the PI served as the thesis advisor for 4 mathematics PhD students (two current students and two who have graduated and subsequently obtained postdoctoral positions, as a Preceptor at Harvard, and a postdoc at Vanderbilt/Yale).For the duration of the grant, the PI served as the main co-organizer of the blended Geometry, Groups and Dynamics/GEAR Seminar at UIUC (most of whose talks are posted online at Youtube). The PI spearheaded, and served as a co-editor of the special Wolfgang Haken volume of the Illinois Journal of Mathematics, published in 2017. As a follow-up event, the PI was the initiator and one of the main co-organizers of the Four Color Fest, held in November 2017 at UIUC to celebrate the 40th anniversary of the Appel-Haken proof of the Four Color Theorem. The PI was also the main organizer of the June 2017 interdisciplinary conference in Hoboken, NJ  "Groups and Computation: Interactions between geometric group theory, computability and computer science". In Spring 2017 the PI has created a new resource for the geometric group theory community worldwide: an automated e-mail list  geom-group-theory@lists.illinois.edu for  announcements of conferences, workshops, and positions in geometric group theory. The list currently has over 450 subscribers. The PI serves as the sole administrator and moderator of the list. The list greatly facilitates the speed and the breadth of the audience reached by various conference announcements, including many NSF funded conferences.
The PI has continued his editing Wikipedia, mainly on mathematical topics, and to date has created 47 Wikipedia articles. (The most recent ones being "Free factor complex", "Muller–Schupp theorem", "Co-Hopfian group", "Howson property", "Bulletin of Mathematical Sciences", "Acylindrically hyperbolic group"). The PI also has given several expository/demonstration talks at mathematical conferences about mathematics Wikipedia editing with the goal of attracting more mathematicians to editing Wikipedia on mathematical and scientific topics.
